alternatives.transcript: Good morning America I'm Charles Gibson and I'm Joan Lunden coming up in our first hour this Wednesday February the 5th the Seattle Mariners are up for sale will baseball at the Japanese buy American

a message from the tobacco industry kids don't smoke the question is that they really mean it it is now 22 minutes before 8:00 the message isn't surprising that cigarettes should not be a part of growing up but the messenger in a new TV campaign to discourage children from smoking is a shock to a lot of people it's the tobacco Institute the very folks who represent the cigarette companies here's a quick look at part of one of the public service announcements this group is putting out to help parents dissuade them

youngsters from smoking the book on growing up what they're going through only looks different from what you went through and there's a lot you can share with them so before your kids make important decisions like smoking talk to them help them decide not to smoke question why is the cigarette Industry Group now sending an anti-smoking message well to help us look for an answer Branden Dawson vice president of the tobacco Institute is joining us

us from Washington and from WCVB in Boston our medical editor dr. Tim Johnson and a good morning to you both Brennan let me start with you do you really want kids not to smoke or is this a PR campaign we really don't want kids to smoke in fact Charlie but his public service announcements that we provided a grant for are an extension of a long history of actions to keep kids from smoking the booklet that they promote tobacco helping you say no which helps parents work with their kids to reduce the peer pressure

frequently the reason why kids smoke has been out for over a year in fact their print ads for them and in the last year almost 200,000 parents have taken the time to call an 800 number or clip a coupon out of TV Guide a Parade Magazine to get the materials and the response has been so positive that working with the experts the family course Consortium of group of Educators and other people who work with children we decided to go on and take this to the next logical step which is television public service announcements

it's very exciting because it gives the opportunity for Millions more people to see and to in fact no of our offer for these free materials that do work that's what parents tell us Brennan there's a lot of money at stake more than three thousand teenagers a day I have read start smoking 3000 everyday start smoking and minors by billions of dollars of cigarettes you're ready to forego all that money absolutely if another child in the United States never picked up a cigarette that would be

just fine with the tobacco companies it's that simple it's not only illegal for children to purchase cigarettes and in fact we've been very active in the last year and helping passed laws to make it illegal for children to buy cigarettes and have been successful in five states and we have five states left to go for 1992 but beyond that there are things that we set aside for adults in the United States whether it's driving or drinking alcoholic beverages or voting or getting married smoking is one of those things you need to be

an adult to have the information and to make a good decision about smoking so let's keep smoking for adults and if that means that the tobacco industry has to keep going with very Innovative programs very active programs to make sure our commitment is understood then that's what we'll do let me move to Tim Johnson Tim you have been highly skeptical of actions by the tobacco Institute in the past to say the least your reaction to this well the actual message I can't disagree with nor the effort of that message that is through parents trying to get kids

stop smoking but I must admit Charlie course I'm as you well know I'm a little slow at 7:30 in the morning I don't quite understand why on the one hand they would send this message with their right hand and then with their left hand clearly be reaching out to young people with all of the seductive advertising I guess I would be really impressed with the commitment of the tobacco industry if they eliminated all of the seductive advertising showing young healthy people having a wonderful time while smoking and just stuck to informational advertising for adults well I was going to ask you

what they would have to do to convince you that they were sincere and I gather that's what you'd say get rid of the advertiser absolutely they will always say of course that they're not appealing to kids with their advertising but they clearly show very young people whatever the ages in their twenties looking very appealing athletic healthy and that's what builds the peer pressure you know young people adolescents are always looking to model what they're slightly older kids are doing or what young people are doing so what would really impress me is to eliminate all of the seduction

of advertising use just hard informational advertising print advertising for the adults they are allegedly trying to reach Brennan have to raise one other point to thoroughly real quickly she talks about this should be an adult Choice the AMA just recently did an extensive survey showing that the vast majority of people start smoking before adulthood and I guess I just ask you and all of our viewers to say how many adults do you know in your own circle of acquaintances who after college age sat down and said you know this smoking makes a lot of sense I think I'm going to start that am a study I think said that 90%

percent of adult smokers started in teens which makes the tobacco Institute to effort all the more interesting but to quickly Brennan let me ask you I seem to remember was it Henry Waxman to introduce the bill last year that would have prevented advertising advertising aimed at young people would you support that there have been a number of bills introduced that would sensor the tobacco industry they range from complete bans on Advertising to things that would just make print ads available that look like stock offers no I wouldn't support that and in fact that

ship it violates the First Amendment and a number of people agree with that on Capitol Hill as well as elsewhere but you know Tim's not going to be satisfied until tobacco ads go away because he doesn't like them but the fact is that whether we look at the experience of other countries who have banned ads where teenage smoking rates can be twice what they are in the United States to the studies that look at why kids smoke and that's peer pressure and we in the family course Consortium are hitting that head-on all right Branden Dawson thanks very much Tim good to see you again thank you for
for being with us as well

thanks Eric research on youth smoking shows that children are heavily influenced by parents friends and family members peer pressure in fact is the single most important motivating factor outside the family through a grant from the tobacco Institute earlier this year the family course Consortium launched a television campaign designed to discourage youngsters from

smoking here with more on the campaign and its message is Tom Lauria from the tobacco Institute good morning good morning my dear coming in thank you this was when I first got this in the mail I said well this is the tobacco Institute and they're saying don't smoke it's that's right it's a bit of a departure from what we usually get from the tobacco Institute what's the thrust behind this so peer pressure is the most probably important motivating factor for kids positive end - that's right the Surgeon General is pointing to peer pressure as a number

of one reason why kids experiment with tobacco we felt the best way to address peer pressure was to put information into the hands of parents and how to communicate better so we have created a campaign called tobacco helping you say no which in fact gives parents the tools they need to talk directly to their kids not lecture them but get to the heart of what influences come to bear on their children whether it's school or the playground or just hang it around like kids do we think that parent Parental Guidance in this area can work

wonders in terms of giving kids a self-esteem they need to turn down that that dare to try to Backhoe or alcohol or drugs or sex so it's included in all of the the so-called evils that are kind of preying on kids these days it's not just smoking right we think that our programs directed at tobacco but it the tools that we give parents can easily be applied to talking about other substances as well theoretically again it if this works a lot of people are going to grow into adulthood

Hood not smoking so be it we understand that there's a lot of concern among the public right now for for underage smoking we believe that smoking is an adult choice but it's one that adults make fully cognizant of the health information they have both in the package and from a myriad of other sources we don't feel the kids evaluate that health information they X spontaneously they will experiment with tobacco because of a dare or because they're curious for new experience it looks cool that's what a lot of kids tell you just looks cool

the sit there with a cigarette in your hand a lot of well it doesn't look cool in fact for the yeah that's their translation fourteen-year-old on a street corner with a cigarette as a terrible advertisement for the prior industry we would just as soon our products be used even if there's less people using them by adults devil who makes the conscious Choice the law says that they can't purchase cigarettes in Louisiana that just changed last year again we helped Lobby for that but we really feel it's important to get information into the hands of parents that's what you've got a series of public service announcements and ads

we're going to be seeing around let's look at the one you brought in today a 30 second announcement on the campaign what they're going through only looks different from what you went through and there's a lot you can share with them so before your kids make important decisions like smoking talk to them help them decide not to smoke everybody needs help talking to their kids sometimes call for your free booklet on how parents can talk to their teenagers about smoking and other tough issues
family cause Consortium belief smoking shouldn't be a part of growing up

yeah I have seen those around there they've got white saturation apparently we sent them to 50 major media markets over 2,000 stations the theme of that ad is quite clearly if you're we're talking to parents and we're saying you were a kid once you know where these kind of pressures come relate your own experiences to your kids and if you need a little help and organizing your thoughts use that toll-free number give us a call we'll send you information that you can use to be effective Communicator with your kids find out where where they're coming from

from and how to talk to them it's you know so often parents get the wrong idea that because of an earring or long hair or a crazy T-shirt that's that's peer pressure is pretty innocent and that's what kit all kids grow out of it usually it's a shame to waste valuable credibility as a parent on how haircut when in fact there are more important things to talk about how the pack of cigarettes in the bacteria or the can of beer I mean both are concerned to the industries who make those products alright thank you so much and the free booklet has a let's get the number of once more for

this is Eyewitness News Daybreak a fresh look at South Florida this morning with our Carlson Peggy Louis world its own eyes with weather and a one and only Eyewitness News Team even those who smoke admit it's a bad habit and most agree that it's best if children don't start smoking to begin with but a new campaign to keep kids off tobacco is teaming up some unlikely factions and education Lobby and the tobacco industry joining us in our Newsroom this morning for jolly and a

none of the family course Consortium and Walker Merriman a spokesman for the tobacco Institute good morning everyone good morning mr. Merriman let's start with you first from the tobacco Institute standpoint this seems like a rather unusual undertaking for you all well it's the sort of thing that we've been doing in terms of policy and in terms of activities for almost 30 years this obviously is a lot more high-profile we have For the First Time released a couple of public service announcements to tell

Vision stations all over the country now more than 160 stations and cable systems are running these public service announcements but our policy is an industry for a very long time has been we don't want kids smoking and we are taking some very firm voluntary initiatives to try to put that policy into practice so much say that and I know that you're working with this probe new program but that the tobacco industry in its advertising in magazines and much of what it does has influenced young people

like to smoke well I guess if that were the case in countries that had banned all tobacco advertising you'd expect to see a decline in smoking amongst youngsters and that simply hasn't happened in Scandinavian countries in Italy and Iceland in Singapore where all advertising of cigarettes has been banned there hasn't been any drop in cigarette consumption among kids or adults advertising doesn't operate that way mr. Davidson Your Role at all of this yes I'm a member of the family course Consortium where group of

individuals representatives from some organizations who are committed to improving Family Life Family communication helping parents help their youngsters make good decisions on a number of tough issues one of which of course is saying no to Tobacco we've come forth with this booklet tobacco helping youth say no a guide for parents is they work with her youngsters and helping them cope with peer pressure because peer pressure is the number one reason why youngsters tries

smoking quick tips on which on what parents can do to stop them one of the best things they can do is instill a great deal of self confidence in their youngsters self-esteem is the best antidote for peer pressure and they also need to spend time visiting with their youngsters questioning them about why why they feel the way they do is some issues we can't always say don't do this that doesn't work we need to find out the reasons why they want to try we want to know their friends we want to be interested in their activities we want

want to teach them how to make good decisions step-by-step and the booklet which is free of charge and available by calling the toll-free number 1-800 34 to 90999 does just that it gives many practical tips for parents to help them with their youngsters resist peer pressure make good decisions and improve Family Life mr. Berryman let's get back to you for just a minute is is the tobacco Institute support of this a tacit admission

the smoking is unhealthy I think that's a very good question I think that what we're trying to do is say to parents and a youngsters that there are an awful lot of things that we either by law or by social custom in this country have always said aren't for kids kids can't by law serve in the armed forces they can't drink alcoholic beverages sign a contract get credit but as an adult you can make a lot of those choices because you are presumed to have

have the Judgment in the maturity that are necessary and we've always said certainly that there are possible risks associated with smoking kids have a lot of health information but they don't have the maturity to make the judge all right mr. so before your kids make important decisions like smoking talk to them help them decide not to smoke everybody needs help talking to their kids sometimes call for your free booklet on how parents can talk to their teenagers about smoking and other tough issues the family course Consortium beliefs smoking shouldn't be a part of growing up

and we have Jolly Davidson with us today a member of the education Consortium that came up with the concepts For Those ads thanks for coming in today I'm more kids smoking now than they did say ten years ago the numbers are down actually they decrease dramatically in the 70s and in the 80s and then we reach rather a plateau the latest figures that we have from the Center for Disease Control tell us that about 11 to 12 percent of teenagers smoke on a regular basis

the numbers down but as far as the tobacco Institute and the family course Consortium they're not low enough all right smoking Society I guess really cracking down on smokers these days you can't smoke in hardly any restaurants anymore that kind of thing is that helping that attitude change is it helping to keep kids off of I think it's helping I also think that the Comprehensive Health courses offered in both public and private schools help to a degree the problem is that

peer pressure is the number one reason why kids try smoking why they try a lot of things we'd rather they not and there really hasn't been anything to address that issue and that's why the course Consortium feels so strongly that the booklet tobacco helping youth say no is a wonderful guide for parents because it helps them as they work with their kids in understanding and coping with peer pressure and teaching him how to make good decisions I don't know if you have this in your booklet there but how do parents

smoke it seems like they would have a bit of a credibility problem in terms of facing their kids and telling them not to smoke how do you tell parents to deal with that beside quitting I guess the obvious answer it's always tougher as a parent to say do as I say not as I do but we do it with a lot of things as adults we do many things that we don't want our youngsters to do I honestly believe that the techniques and the suggestions that we offer in the free booklet tobacco hoping you'd say no work just

as well with a little more effort for parents who smoke as those who do not own that same idea it's also interesting for the tobacco industry to be paying for these ads because they know the industry is even come under Fire recently for possibly try to tailor some of the Billboards cartoon characters and that type of thing to appeal to a younger audience the seems to go against that we've heard a lot about advertising and the effect that it's supposed to have on youngsters smoking actually all research tells us that it is an advertising it is

peer pressure and the tobacco Institute which is the trade Association for all of the tobacco companies they have done many things over the years to discourage young people from smoking but this is their most I think they're most forceful move that they have made with the booklet with the PSAs the Consortium also has speakers bureaus we do workshops in at-risk neighborhoods and interestingly enough a native of Nevada Rosemary Clark who served on your State Board of Education

was one of the peer review members on the booklet tobacco helping you say no we're out of time but I want to let people know where can they get a copy of the booklet they call one eight hundred three four two nine zero nine nine and request their free copy or multiple copies for educators or youth workers tobacco helping youth say no okay thank you for coming in today thank you
